articles.headline: In Tennessee Corner, Stimulus Meets New Deal
articles.snippet: Rather than waiting for big projects to be planned, Tennessee is using stimulus money to subsidize new jobs.
articles.abstract: Rather than waiting for big projects to be planned, Tennessee is using stimulus money to subsidize new jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINDEN, Tenn.  Critics elsewhere may be questioning how many jobs the stimulus program has created, but here in central Tennessee, hundreds of workers are again drawing paychecks after many months out of work, thanks to a novel use of federal stimulus money by state officials.

articles.headline: In Study, Texting Lifts Crash Risk by Large Margin
articles.snippet: For truck drivers videotaped for 18 months during a study, texting was found to be the riskiest distraction.
articles.abstract: For truck drivers videotaped for 18 months during a study, texting was found to be the riskiest distraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first study of drivers texting inside their vehicles shows that the risk sharply exceeds previous estimates based on laboratory research  and far surpasses the dangers of other driving distractions.

articles.headline: Young Japanese Women Vie for a Once-Scorned Job
articles.snippet: Once derided as immodest, hostessing, a job in which young women lavish attention on affluent men, has become a popular and respected profession.
articles.abstract: Once derided as immodest, hostessing, a job in which young women lavish attention on affluent men, has become a popular and respected profession.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  The women who pour drinks in Japan’s sleek gentlemen’s clubs were once shunned because their duties were considered immodest: lavishing adoring (albeit nonsexual) attention on men for a hefty fee.

articles.headline: Landowners Still in Exile From Unstable Pakistan Area
articles.snippet: After fleeing the Taliban, landowners are not coming back to the Swat Valley, in a blow to Pakistan’s effort to restore stability.
articles.abstract: After fleeing the Taliban, landowners are not coming back to the Swat Valley, in a blow to Pakistan’s effort to restore stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Even as hundreds of thousands of people stream back to the Swat Valley after months of fighting, one important group is conspicuously absent: the wealthy landowners who fled the Taliban in fear and are the economic pillar of the rural society.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Silverman Quits NBC Universal; Cable Executive Succeeds Him
articles.snippet: The changes at NBC Universal’s television entertainment unit are seen as a sign that cable TV is in the ascendancy over traditional broadcasting.
articles.abstract: The changes at NBC Universal’s television entertainment unit are seen as a sign that cable TV is in the ascendancy over traditional broadcasting.
articles.lead_paragraph: The deal maker is gone. Now it’s the cable guy’s turn.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Health Policy Is Carved Out at Table for 6
articles.snippet: The health system overhaul largely rests on six senators who have tossed aside core Democratic priorities.
articles.abstract: The health system overhaul largely rests on six senators who have tossed aside core Democratic priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On the agenda is the revamping of the American health care system, possibly the most complex legislation in modern history. But on the table, in a conference room where the bill is being hashed out by six senators, the snacks are anything but healthy.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Robert Pear

articles.headline: A Debate Rages in Iceland: Independence vs. I.M.F. Cash
articles.snippet: The island nation is locked in a fierce debate over how to pay off its creditors without ceding too much of its vaunted independence.
articles.abstract: The island nation is locked in a fierce debate over how to pay off its creditors without ceding too much of its vaunted independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  Just months after an epic banking collapse forced Iceland into the arms of the International Monetary Fund, this island nation is locked in a fierce debate over how to pay off its creditors without ceding too much of its vaunted independence.

articles.headline: Netflix Competitors Learn the Power of Teamwork
articles.snippet: A contest with a $1 million prize for improving on Netflix’s movie recommendations ended in a dead heat, but has already produced an impressive legacy.
articles.abstract: A contest with a $1 million prize for improving on Netflix’s movie recommendations ended in a dead heat, but has already produced an impressive legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: A contest set up by Netflix, which offered a $1 million prize to anyone who could significantly improve its movie recommendation system, ended on Sunday with two teams in a virtual dead heat, and no winner to be declared until September.

articles.headline: Politicians Accused of Meddling in Bank Rules
articles.snippet: Accounting rules did not cause the financial crisis, and they still allow banks to overstate the value of their assets, according to a report to be released Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Accounting rules did not cause the financial crisis, and they still allow banks to overstate the value of their assets, according to a report to be released Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Accounting rules did not cause the financial crisis, and they still allow banks to overstate the value of their assets, an international group composed of current and former regulators and corporate officials said in a report to be released Tuesday.

articles.headline: Reports of Prison Abuse and Deaths Anger Iranians
articles.snippet: Stories of abuse, relayed by relatives and on Web sites, in Iran’s post-election crackdown have provoked outrage, including among prominent conservatives.
articles.abstract: Stories of abuse, relayed by relatives and on Web sites, in Iran’s post-election crackdown have provoked outrage, including among prominent conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Some prisoners say they watched fellow detainees being beaten to death by guards in overcrowded, stinking holding pens. Others say they had their fingernails ripped off or were forced to lick filthy toilet bowls.

articles.headline: Recovery Signs in Housing Market Stir Some Hope
articles.snippet: After a plunge lasting three years, houses have become cheap enough to lure buyers, raising hopes that the housing market has finally hit bottom.
articles.abstract: After a plunge lasting three years, houses have become cheap enough to lure buyers, raising hopes that the housing market has finally hit bottom.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a plunge lasting three years, houses have finally become cheap enough to lure buyers. That, in turn, is stabilizing prices, generating hope that the real estate market is beginning to recover.
